009
010package imagingbook.common.noise.perlin;
011
012import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
013import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.IncompatibleDimensionsException;
014import imagingbook.common.noise.hashing.HashFunction;
015
016/**
017 * <p>
018 * This class implements an N-dimensional Perlin noise [1] generator. See Ch. 8
019 * of [2] for details.
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * [1] K. Perlin. Improving noise. In "SIGGRAPH’02: Proceedings of the 29th
023 * Annual Conference on Computer Graphics and Interactive Techniques", pp.
024 * 681–682, San Antonio, Texas (2002).<br>
025 * [2] W. Burger and M.J. Burge. "Principles of Digital Image Processing -
026 * Advanced Methods" (Vol. 3). Undergraduate Topics in Computer Science.
027 * Springer-Verlag, London (2013).
028 * </p>
029 * 
030 * @author WB
031 * @version 2022/11/24
032 */
033public class PerlinNoiseGeneratorNd extends PerlinNoiseGenerator {
034        
035        private final int N;            // dimensionality
036        private final int K;            // number of hypercube vertices, default 2
037        private final int[][] Q;        // vertex coordinates of the unit hypercube
038                
039        /**
040         * Constructor.
041         * @param N number of dimensions
042         * @param f_min minimum frequency
043         * @param f_max maximum frequency
044         * @param persistence persistence
045         * @param hf hash function
046         */
047        public PerlinNoiseGeneratorNd(int N, double f_min, double f_max, double persistence, HashFunction hf) {
048                super(f_min, f_max, persistence, hf);
049                this.N = N;
050                this.K = (int) Math.pow(2, N);  // number of hypercube vertices
051                this.Q = new int[K][N];                 // vertices of the unit hypercube
052                for (int j = 0; j < K; j++) {
053                        Q[j] = vertex(j, N);
054                }
055        }
056        
057        /**
058         * N-dim combined (multi-frequency) Perlin noise function. 
059         * @param X Interpolation position X (N-dimensional).
060         * @return The value of the combined Perlin
061         * noise function for the N-dimensional position X.
062         */
063        public double getNoiseValue(double[] X) {
064                double sum = 0;
065                for (int i = 0; i < F.length; i++) { // for all frequencies
066                        sum = sum + A[i] * noise(Matrix.multiply(F[i], X));
067                }
068                return sum;
069        }
070        
071        /**
072         * 2D elementary (single-frequency) Perlin noise function. 
073         * @param X Interpolation position X (N-dimensional).
074         * @return The value of the elementary Perlin
075         * noise function for the N-dimensional position X.
076         */
077        private double noise(double[] X) {
078                int[] P0 = floor(X);            // origin of hypercube around X
079                 
080                // get the 2^N gradient vectors for all hypercube corners:
081                double[][] G = new double[K][N];
082                for(int j=0; j<K; j++) {        
083                        G[j] = gradient(add(P0,Q[j]));                  // gradient vector at cube corner j
084                }
085                
086                double[] X01 = subtract(X,P0);                                  // X01[k] are in [0,1]
087                
088                // get the 2^N gradient values at all vertices for position X
089                double[] W = new double[K];
090                for (int j = 0; j < K; j++) {   
091                        W[j] = Matrix.dotProduct(G[j], subtract(X01, Q[j]));
092                }
093                
094                return interpolate(X01, W, 0);
095        }
096        
097        /**
098         * @param p discrete position.
099         * @return A pseudo-random gradient vector for 
100         * the discrete lattice point p (N-dimensional).
101         */
102        private double[] gradient(int[] p) {    
103                if (p.length == 2) {
104                        return gradient(p[0],p[1]);
105                }
106                // hash() always returns a new double[], g[i] in [0,1]
107                double[] g = hashFun.hash(p);   // STILL TO BE DONE!!!
108                for (int i=0; i<g.length; i++) {
109                        g[i] = 2.0 * g[i] - 1;
110                }
111                return g;
112        }
113        
114        /**
115         * Local interpolation function (recursive).
116         * @param X01 Interpolation position in [0,1]^N
117         * @param WW  A vector of length 2^(N-d) with
118         * the tangent values for the hypercube corners.
119         * @param k The interpolation dimension (axis).
120         * @return  The interpolated noise value at position X01.
121         */
122        private double interpolate(double[] X01, double[] WW, int k) {
123                if (WW.length == 1) { // (d == N)
124                        return WW[0]; // done, end of recursion
125                } else { // d < N
126                        double x01 = X01[k]; // select dimension d of vector X
127                        double s = this.s(x01); // blending function
128                        int M = WW.length / 2;
129                        double[] W = new double[M]; // W is half the length of WW
130                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
131                                double wa = WW[2 * i];
132                                double wb = WW[2 * i + 1];
133                                W[i] = (1 - s) * wa + s * wb; // the actual interpolation
134                        }
135                        return interpolate(X01, W, k + 1);
136                }
137        }
138
139        /**
140         * @param j Vertex number (0..2^N-1)
141         * @param N Dimension of the hypercube
142         * @return The coordinate vector for vertex j of the N-dimensional
143         * hypercube.
144         */
145        private int[] vertex(int j, int N) { 
146                int[] v = new int[N];
147                // copy the bit representation of j into v,
148                // v[0] is the most significant bit 
149                for (int k = 0; k < N; k++) {
150                         v[k] = j & 0x00000001;         // select least significant bit (bit 0)
151                         j = j >>> 1;                           // j <- j/2
152                }
153                return v;
154        }
155        
156        // from 2D example
157        private double[] gradient(int i, int j) {
158                double[] g = hashFun.hash(i,j);         // hash() always returns a new double[]
159                g[0] = 2.0 * g[0] - 1;
160                g[1] = 2.0 * g[1] - 1;
161                return g;
162        }
163        
164        private double[] subtract(double[] a, int[] b) {
165                if (a.length != b.length)
166                        throw new IncompatibleDimensionsException();
167                final int n = a.length;
168                double[] c = new double[n];
169                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
170                        c[i] = a[i] - b[i];
171                }
172                return c;
173        }
174        
175        private int[] add(int[] a, int[] b) {
176                if (a.length != b.length)
177                        throw new IncompatibleDimensionsException();
178                final int n = a.length;
179                int[] c = new int[n];
180                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
181                        c[i] = c[i] + b[i];
182                }
183                return c;
184        }
185        
186        private int[] floor(double[] a) {
187                int[] b = new int[a.length];
188                for (int i = 0; i < a.length; i++) {
189                        b[i] = (int) Math.floor(a[i]);
190                }
191                return b;
192        }
193
194}
